A Patient has prosthetic valve. After 8 months he developed endocarditis what can be the causative organism
Which of the following is a feature of first degree AV block?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sol:
  • ↳ Electrocardiography and electrophysiology of AV conduction block:
  • ↳ Atrioventricular conduction block typically is diagnosed electrocardiographically, which characterizes the severity of the conduction disturbance and allows one to draw inferences about the location of the block. AV conduction block manifests as slow conduction in its mildest forms and failure to conduct, either intermittent or persistently, in more severe varieties.
  • ↳ First-degree AV block (PR interval >200 ms) is a slowing of conduction through the AV junction.
  • ↳ The site of delay is typically in the AV node but may be in the atria, bundle of His, or His-Purkinje system.
  • ↳ A wide QRS is suggestive of delay in the distal conduction system, whereas a narrow QRS suggests delay in the AV node proper or, less commonly, in the bundle of HIS.
  • ↳ IN second degree AV block there is an intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from atrium to ventricle.
  • ↳ Second-degree AV block is subclassified as Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) or Mobitz type II.
  • ↳ The periodic failure of conduction in Mobitz type I block is characterized by a progressively lengthening PR interval, shortening of the RR interval, and a pause that is less than two times the immediately preceding RR interval on the ECG.
  • ↳ The ECG complex after the pause exhibits a shorter PR interval than that immediately preceding the pause.
  • ↳ This ECG pattern most often arise because of decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node.

questions.text: Which of the following is an electrocardiographic feature of pulmonary hypertension?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sol:
  • ↳ The electrocardiogram (ECG) of a patient with PH may demonstrate. Sign of right ventricular hypertrophy or strain including :-
  • ↳ The electrocardiogram (ECG) of a patient with PH may demonstrate.
  • ↳ Sign of right ventricular hypertrophy or strain including :-
  • ↳ Right axis deviation, an R wave/S wave ratio greater than one lead V1 (dominant R wave). Incomplete or complete right bundle branch block, or increased P wave amplitude in lead II (P pulmonale) due to right atrial enlargement. T wave inversion Sinus tachycardia
  • ↳ Right axis deviation, an R wave/S wave ratio greater than one lead V1 (dominant R wave).
  • ↳ Incomplete or complete right bundle branch block, or increased P wave amplitude in lead II (P pulmonale) due to right atrial enlargement.
  • ↳ T wave inversion
  • ↳ Sinus tachycardia

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with HLA-B27Which of the following is not associated with HLA-B27
Murmur best heard with Valsalva maneuver
Cause of nephrocalcinosis in granulomatous disease
Pseudobulbar palsy is seen with
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sol:
  • ↳ Upper motor neuron weakness
  • ↳ This pattern of weakness results from disorders that affect the upper motor neurons or their axons in the cerebral cortex, subcortical white matter, internal capsule, brainstem, or spinal cord. These lesions produce weakness through decreased activation of the lower motor neurons. In general, distal muscle groups are affected more severely than are proximal ones, and axial movements are spared unless the lesion is severe and bilateral. With corticobulbar involvement, weakness usually is observed only in the lower face and tounge; extraocular , upper facial, pharyngeal, and jaw muscles almost always are spared. With bilateral cortocobulbar lesions, pseudobulbar palsy often develops: dysarthria, dysphagia, dysphonia, and emotional lability accompany bilateral facial weakness and a brisk jaw jerk. Spasticity accompanies upper motor neuron weakness but neuron weakness but may not be present in the acute phase. Upper moter neuron lesions also affect the ability to perform rapid repetitive movements. Such movements are slow and coarse, but nornmal hythimicty is maintained. Finger-nose-finger and heel-knee shin maneuvers are performed slowely but adequately.
  • ↳ This pattern of weakness results from disorders that affect the upper motor neurons or their axons in the cerebral cortex, subcortical white matter, internal capsule, brainstem, or spinal cord.
  • ↳ These lesions produce weakness through decreased activation of the lower motor neurons. In general, distal muscle groups are affected more severely than are proximal ones, and axial movements are spared unless the lesion is severe and bilateral.
  • ↳ With corticobulbar involvement, weakness usually is observed only in the lower face and tounge; extraocular , upper facial, pharyngeal, and jaw muscles almost always are spared.
  • ↳ With bilateral cortocobulbar lesions, pseudobulbar palsy often develops: dysarthria, dysphagia, dysphonia, and emotional lability accompany bilateral facial weakness and a brisk jaw jerk.
  • ↳ Spasticity accompanies upper motor neuron weakness but neuron weakness but may not be present in the acute phase.
  • ↳ Upper moter neuron lesions also affect the ability to perform rapid repetitive movements.
  • ↳ Such movements are slow and coarse, but nornmal hythimicty is maintained.
  • ↳ Finger-nose-finger and heel-knee shin maneuvers are performed slowely but adequately.
